country.name: Wallis and Futuna
country.background: The Futuna island group was discovered by the Dutch in 1616 and Wallis by the British in 1767, but it was the French who declared a protectorate over the islands in 1842, and took official control of them between 1886 and 1888. Notably, Wallis and Futuna was the only French colony to side with the Vichy regime during World War II, a phase that ended in May of 1942 with the arrival of 2,000 American troops. In 1959, the inhabitants of the islands voted to become a French overseas territory and officially assumed this status in July 1961.

geo.note: both island groups have fringing reefs

location.desc: Oceania, islands in the South Pacific Ocean, about two-thirds of the way from Hawaii to New Zealand

area.comparison: 1.5 times the size of Washington, DC

geo.climate: tropical; hot, rainy season (November to April); cool, dry season (May to October); rains 2,500-3,000 mm per year (80% humidity); average temperature 26.6 degrees C
geo.issues: deforestation (only small portions of the original forests remain) largely as a result of the continued use of wood as the main fuel source; as a consequence of cutting down the forests, the mountainous terrain of Futuna is particularly prone to erosion; there are no permanent settlements on Alofi because of the lack of natural freshwater resources

nationality.noun: Wallisian(s), Futunan(s), or Wallis and Futuna Islanders
nationality.adjective: Wallisian, Futunan, or Wallis and Futuna Islander

people.languages: Wallisian (indigenous Polynesian language) 58.9%, Futunian 30.1%, French (official) 10.8%, other 0.2% (2003 census)

literacy.definition: age 15 and over can read and write

country-name.long: Territory of the Wallis and Futuna Islands

capital.name: Mata-Utu (on Ile Uvea)
capital.time-difference: UTC+12 (17 hours ahead of Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.administrative-divisions: none (overseas territory of France); there are no first-order administrative divisions as defined by the US Government, but there are three kingdoms at the second order named Alo, Sigave, Wallis

executive.head-of-state: President Nicolas SARKOZY (since 16 May 2007); represented by High Administrator Michel JEANJEAN (since 10 June 2010)
executive.head-of-government: President of the Territorial Assembly Victor BRIAL (since 11 December 2007)
executive.cabinet: Council of the Territory consists of 3 kings and 3 members appointed by the high administrator on the advice of the Territorial Assembly
executive.elections: French president elected by popular vote for a five-year term; high administrator appointed by the French president on the advice of the French Ministry of the Interior; the presidents of the Territorial Government and the Territorial Assembly elected by the members of the assembly

legislative.description: unicameral Territorial Assembly or Assemblee Territoriale (20 seats; members elected by popular vote to serve five-year terms)
legislative.elections: last held on 1 April 2007 (next to be held in April 2012)
legislative.election-results: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - UMP 13, other 7

government.judicial: justice generally administered under French law by the high administrator, but the three traditional kings administer customary law and there is a magistrate in Mata-Utu; a court of appeal is located in Noumea, New Caledonia
government.parties: Lua Kae Tahi (Giscardians); Mouvement des Radicaux de Gauche or MRG; Rally for the Republic or RPR (UMP); Socialist Party or PS; Taumu'a Lelei; Union Populaire Locale or UPL; Union Pour la Democratie Francaise or UDF

economy.overview: The economy is limited to traditional subsistence agriculture, with about 80% of labor force earnings from agriculture (coconuts and vegetables), livestock (mostly pigs), and fishing. About 4% of the population is employed in government. Revenues come from French Government subsidies, licensing of fishing rights to Japan and South Korea, import taxes, and remittances from expatriate workers in New Caledonia.
economy.agriculture-products: coconuts, breadfruit, yams, taro, bananas; pigs, goats; fish
economy.exchange-rates: Comptoirs Francais du Pacifique francs (XPF) per US dollar -

communications.broadcast: the publicly-owned French Overseas Network (RFO), which broadcasts to France's overseas departments and territories, is carried on the RFO Wallis and Fortuna television and radio stations (2008)

manpower.notes: defense is the responsibility of France
